message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A spinal cord hemisection refers to a lesion that affects only one side of the spinal cord. The symptoms are usually ipsilateral (on the same side as the lesion) loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation, and contralateral (on the opposite side of the lesion) loss of pain and temperature sensation. There is also ipsilateral paresis, or weakness. Therefore, the answer is (A), which includes right-sided tactile, vibration, and proprioception loss (ipsilateral), left-sided pain and temperature sensation loss (contralateral), and right-sided paresis (ipsilateral).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Spinal cord hemisection results in ipsilateral loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. It also results in ipsilateral paresis. In this case, the right-sided tactile, vibration, and proprioception loss, left-sided pain and temperature sensation loss, and right-sided paresis would support the diagnosis of right-sided spinal cord hemisection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Spinal cord hemisection involves damage to one half of the spinal cord, which will result in ipsilateral (same-side) loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation, while contralateral (opposite-side) loss of pain and temperature sensation. Paresis on the same side as the lesion may also occur. Therefore, option A is correct as it includes right-sided loss of tactile, vibration and proprioception sensation, left-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation, and right-sided paresis which are all consistent with a right-sided spinal cord hemisection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Spinal cord hemisection results in ipsilateral loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. In addition, there is paresis on the affected side. Therefore, the most likely neurologic findings would be right-sided tactile, vibration, and proprioception loss; left-sided pain and temperature sensation loss; and right-sided paresis. This is only found in option A.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Spinal cord hemisection causes loss of function on the same side as the injury for tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation, and loss of function on the opposite side for pain and temperature sensation. The paresis is also on the same side as the injury. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question describes a right-sided spinal cord hemisection, which can cause loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation on the right side of the body, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side (left) of the body. Paresis (muscle weakness or paralysis) is also expected on the right side of the body. Option A describes this combination of findings, while the other options have inaccuracies in the side of sensory or motor deficits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Spinal cord hemisection results in ipsilateral loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion, as well as ipsilateral paresis. Therefore, the most likely neurologic findings to support the diagnosis of right-sided spinal cord hemisection would be right-sided tactile, vibration, and proprioception loss; left-sided pain and temperature sensation loss; and right-sided paresis, as listed in option (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Spinal cord hemisection typically results in ipsilateral (same side) loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception and contralateral (opposite side) loss of pain and temperature sensation, as well as ipsilateral paresis (weakness or paralysis). Among the options, only option A fits this pattern with right-sided loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception and left-sided loss of pain and temperature sensation, as well as right-sided paresis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The spinal cord hemisection on the right side would affect the dorsal columns and motor tracts on the same side, resulting in loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception sensation on the right side and paresis on the right side. However, pain and temperature sensation would be lost on the opposite side, in this case the left side. Therefore, the most likely neurologic finding to support the diagnosis would be right-sided tactile, vibration, and proprioception loss; left-sided pain and temperature sensation loss; and right-sided paresis. This option is (A).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to half of the cord, resulting in ipsilateral (same side) loss of tactile, vibration, and proprioception (sensory functions) and contralateral (opposite side) loss of pain and temperature sensation. Paresis (weakness) will also be on the same side as the sensory loss, resulting in right-sided paresis in this case. Option (A) matches these criteria, indicating right-sided spinal cord hemisection.
